Thus have I heard:
At one time the Blessed One was in the Nyagrodha Park of the city of Kapila, together with a great assembly of monks, innumerable people.
At that time the World-Honored One had a younger brother named Nanda, whose body was golden in color, endowed with thirty marks, four fingers shorter than the Buddha.
His wife was named SundarÄ«, whose appearance was upright and proper, rarely seen in the world, with radiance surpassing all, delightful to behold.
Nanda was entangled and attached to her, never leaving her for a moment, with heavy feelings of desire, vowing to die with her.

The World-Honored One, knowing that the time had come for her to be transformed, in the morning put on his robes and took his alms bowl, with the Venerable Ä€nanda as his attendant, entered the city to beg for food, and arrived at Nanda's door. He stood there and emitted golden light with the power of great compassion, the light illuminating Nanda's house, all becoming golden in color.
At that time, Nanda thought:
The sudden illumination must be the Tathagata.
He sent someone out to look and saw the Buddha had arrived. He then quickly returned and said to Nanda:
The World-Honored One is at the gate.
Hearing this, he wanted to quickly go out to welcome and pay homage to the World-Honored One.
At that time, Sundari thought:
If I let him go, the World-Honored One will definitely allow him to go forth.
She then grabbed his robe and pulled him back, not letting him go out.
Nanda said:
Now, let me go for a while.
After paying homage to the World-Honored One, I will immediately return.
Sundari said:
Make a promise with me before you can go as you wish.
She then applied wet ointment to his forehead and told him:
Before this mark dries, you must return. If you delay, you will be fined five hundred gold coins.ğŸ”½Nanda said:
Alright.

He then went to the gate, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, took the TathÄgata's bowl, went back into the house, filled it with delicious food, and brought it to the gate. The World-Honored One then left.
He gave it to Ä€nanda, but the World-Honored One made a gesture not to take the bowl.
The TathÄgata, the Great Teacher, was majestic and venerable, so he did not dare to call him to stop. He then passed it on to Ä€nanda.
Ä€nanda asked:
To whom did you get this bowl from?
He replied:
I got it from the Buddha.
Ä€nanda said:
You should give it to the Buddha.
He replied:
I dare not lightly touch the Great Teacher now.
He silently followed along.
When the World-Honored One arrived at the monastery, he washed his hands and feet, sat down in his seat, and Nanda brought the bowl to him.
After the World-Honored One finished eating, he said:
Nanda!
Do you want to eat my leftovers?
He replied:
I will eat.
The Buddha then gave it to him.
After Nanda had eaten, the World-Honored One said:
Can you go forth?
He replied:
I can go forth.

However, when the World-Honored Buddha was practicing the bodhisattva path in the past, he never disobeyed the instructions of his parents, teachers, and other venerable ones, and therefore now there is no one who disobeys his words.
He then told Ä€nanda:
You may shave Nanda's beard and hair.
He replied:
As the World-Honored One instructs.
He then sought a barber to shave his head.
When Nanda saw this, he told the man:
Do you know now?
I will soon become a wheel-turning king.
If you rashly shave my hair, I will cut off your wrist.
He became greatly frightened, wrapped up his razor, and was about to take leave and leave.
At that time, Ä€nanda went to tell the Buddha.
The Buddha then went himself to Nanda's place and asked:
Nanda!
Have you not left the household life?
He replied:
I have left the household life.
At that time the World-Honored One himself held a water pot and poured water over his head, and the barber shaved him.
He then thought:
I now respectfully serve the World-Honored One, leaving the household life in the morning and returning home in the evening.
When it was late in the day, he followed the road and walked. At that time, the World-Honored One magically created a large pit on the road he was walking on.
Seeing it, he thought of SundarÄ«, realizing it was far away and there was no way to go back. He thought, If I remember her, I may die. If I am still alive, I will go at dawn.
Remembering SundarÄ«, he suffered all night long.
At that time, the World-Honored One knew his thoughts and told Ä€nanda:
You should go now and tell Nanda to be the one in charge of affairs.
He then went to report:
The World-Honored One wants you to be the one in charge of affairs.
He asked:
What is meant by being the one in charge of affairs?
What do you wish to do?
He replied:
I can inspect the various affairs in the temple.
He asked:
How should I act?
He replied:
Venerable!
If the monks go out to beg for food, you should sprinkle and sweep the temple grounds, take fresh cow dung and apply it in order, and be careful to guard against loss.

If there are matters to be discussed, you should inform the Sangha. If there are incense and flowers, you should distribute them to the assembly. At night, close the doors and open them at dawn. Always clean the toilets. If there is any damage in the temple, you should repair it.
Having heard this instruction, he replied:
Venerable!
I will do as the Buddha has said.
Then the monks, at the time of the morning meal, took their robes and bowls and entered the city of Kapilavastu to beg for food.
At that time, Nanda saw that there was no one in the temple, and he thought like this:
After I sweep the ground, I can go home.
So he began to sweep the ground.
The World-Honored One observed and knew this, and with his spiritual powers, he caused the clean area that had been swept to be filled with filth again.
He thought like this again:
After I remove the filth, I can then say I'm going back.
He released the broom and collected the filth, but it was endless.
He thought like this again:
I'll close the door and leave.
The World-Honored One then caused him to close one room, and after closing the other doors, those doors opened again.
He became worried and thought like this again:
Even if the thieves damage the temple, what harm is there?
I will become the king and build hundreds of thousands of excellent temples, even better than this.
I should return home.
If I take the main road, I'm afraid I'll see the World-Honored One.
Thinking like this, he took a small path.
The Buddha knew his thoughts and came from the small path.
Seeing the Buddha from afar, he did not want to meet him. There was a tree by the side of the road with low-hanging branches, so he hid his body under it.
The Buddha caused the tree to raise its branches high, revealing his body. The Buddha asked Nanda:
Where have you come from?
You should follow me back.
Feeling ashamed, he followed the Buddha.
The Buddha thought:
He is deeply attached to his wife and cannot let go.
In order to guide him, he left the city of Kapilavastu and went to ÅšrÄvastÄ«. Having arrived there, he stayed in the garden of VisÄkhÄ, the mother of Má¹›gÄra's son.
The Buddha thought that Nanda was foolish and deluded, still thinking of his wife and unable to let go of his love. He should use skillful means to make his mind calm down. He then told him:
Have you ever seen GandhamÄdana Mountain?
He replied:
No, I have not seen it.
If that is so, then hold onto the corner of my robe.
He then held onto the Buddha's robe.
At that time, the World-Honored One, like a king of geese, rose into the sky and went to Gandhamadana Mountain.
Leading Nanda, he looked to the left and right. Under a fruit tree, he saw a female monkey with only one eye. She then raised her face and looked straight at the World-Honored One.
The Buddha told Nanda:
Do you see this blind monkey?
He replied to the Buddha:
I see her.
The Buddha said:
What do you think?
Which is more outstanding, this blind monkey or Sundari?
He replied:
Sundari is of the Shakya clan, like a heavenly maiden, with the most dignified appearance, unmatched in the world.
Compared to her, even a thousand millionth part of a monkey is not enough.
The Buddha said:
Have you seen the heavenly palace?
He replied:
I have not seen it.
You can hold onto the corner of my robe again.
He then grasped the robe.
Then, like a king of geese, he ascended into the sky to the Heaven of the Thirty-three and said to Nanda:
You should observe the excellent places in the heavenly palace.

Nanda then went to the Joyful Garden, the Attendant Body Garden, the Rough Body Garden, the Intertwined Garden, the Kalpa Tree, the Hall of Good Dharma, and other such places, the heavenly gardens, groves, flowers, fruits, bathing pools, and places of amusement, all of which were supremely delightful, and he thoroughly examined them all.

Next, he entered the city of SudarÅ›ana and saw the various sounds of drums, string and wind instruments, the spacious corridors and chambers, the curtains and furnishings, and everywhere the heavenly celestial maidens amusing themselves together.
Nanda looked around and saw a place where there were only heavenly maidens and no heavenly sons. He then asked the heavenly maidens, saying:
Why is it that in the other places the men and women live together and enjoy various pleasures, but why is it that you only have women and do not see men?

The World-Honored One has a younger brother named Nanda who has left home to cultivate the holy life under the Buddha. After his life ends, he will be reborn here.
We will wait for each other here.
When Nanda heard this, he was overjoyed and quickly returned to where the Buddha was.
The World-Honored One asked:
Did you see the wonderful things of the devas?
He replied:
I saw them.
The Buddha said:
What did you see?
He told the World-Honored One in detail what he had seen.
The Buddha told Nanda:
Did you see the celestial maidens?
He replied:
I saw them.
Comparing these celestial maidens to Sundari, which is more wonderful?
He said:
World-Honored One!
Comparing Sundari to these celestial maidens is like comparing a blind monkey in the Gandhamadana Mountains to Sundari - a hundred thousand million times, not even a hundredth part.
The Buddha told Nanda:
The practitioner of pure conduct has such benefits.
You should now firmly cultivate pure conduct, and you will be born in the heavens to experience this happiness.
Having heard this, he joyfully remained silent.
At that time, the World-Honored One then left the heavens with Nanda and arrived at Jetavana.
At that time, Nanda, thinking of the heavenly palace, cultivated pure conduct. The Buddha knew his thoughts and told Ananda:

You should now go and tell the bhikshus that no one should sit on the same seat as Nanda, walk in the same place, hang robes on the same pole, place bowls or water bottles in the same place, or read and recite sutras in the same place.
Ananda conveyed the Buddha's instructions to the bhikshus, and the bhikshus all followed the holy instructions.
At that time, Nanda, seeing that everyone did not associate with him, felt extremely ashamed.
Later, at one time, Ä€nanda was in the service hall with the bhiká¹£us mending clothes. Seeing this, Nanda thought:
These bhiká¹£us all abandon me and do not stay together.
This Ä€nanda is my younger brother. How could he dislike me?
He then went to sit together with him.
At that time, Ä€nanda quickly got up and avoided him.
He said:
Ä€nanda!
The other bhiká¹£us may be seen as abandoned, but you are my younger brother. Why do you also dislike me?
Ä€nanda said:
This is indeed the case.
However, you practice a different path, and I follow a different way. Therefore, I avoid you.
He replied:ğŸ”½What is my path?
What is your way?
He replied:
You enjoy being born in the heavens and cultivate pure conduct, while I seek complete nirvana and eliminate desire and defilements.
Having heard these words, he became even more worried and distressed.
At that time, the World-Honored One, knowing his thoughts, told Nanda:
Have you ever seen the hells?
He replied:
No, I have not seen them.
The Buddha said:
You can hold onto the corner of my robe.
He then grasped it, and the Buddha took him to the hells.
At that time, the World-Honored One stood to one side and told Nanda:
You can go now and observe the hells.
Nanda went and first saw the river of ashes, then the sword trees, excrement, and river of fire. He entered and observed them.

He saw sentient beings undergoing various sufferings, some with tongs pulling out tongues, twisting teeth, and gouging out eyes, some being sawed apart with saws, some being chopped with axes, some being stabbed with spears, some being beaten with clubs and pierced with lances, some being crushed with iron hammers, some having molten copper poured into their mouths, some climbing knife mountains and sword trees, being pounded with pestles and ground with stones, and suffering the utmost pain on copper pillars and iron beds, some seeing iron cauldrons with raging fires boiling and hot flames surging, cooking sentient beings, seeing such suffering events.
Furthermore, in one iron cauldron, it was boiling empty, with no sentient beings inside.
Seeing this, he was worried and asked the jailer:
For what reason are sentient beings being cooked in the other iron cauldrons, but this cauldron is boiling empty?
He then replied:
Buddha's brother Nanda, only wishing to be reborn in the heavens, single-mindedly cultivated pure conduct, and was reborn in the heavens to temporarily experience happiness.
After their death, they will enter this cauldron. Therefore, I am now lighting the cauldron and waiting for them.
When Nanda heard this, he became greatly frightened, his body hair stood on end, and cold sweat flowed out. He thought:
If he knows I am Nanda, he will throw me into the cauldron.
He then quickly ran to where the World-Honored One was.
The Buddha said:
Have you seen the hells?
Nanda wept sorrowfully, choked with sobs, and said in a faint voice:
I have seen them.
The Buddha said:
What did you see?
He then told the World-Honored One in detail what he had seen.
The Buddha told Nanda:
If one aspires for the human realm or seeks the heavenly realm and diligently cultivates pure conduct, there are such faults. Therefore, you should now seek nirvana.
Cultivate pure conduct, do not delight in being reborn in the heavens and bring about hardship.
When Nanda heard this, he felt ashamed and remained silent without responding.
At that time, the World-Honored One, knowing their thoughts, emerged from the hells and returned to Jetavana. He then told Nanda and the other bhiká¹£us:
There are three defilements within, namely lust, anger, and ignorance. These should be abandoned and avoided.
One should cultivate and study the Dharma.

At that time, not long after the World-Honored One stayed at Jetavana, in order to transform sentient beings according to conditions, he went with his disciples to the country of Vamsa and stayed by the side of the GaggarÄ Lake.
At that time, Nanda and five hundred bhiká¹£us also followed the Buddha to the place of the World-Honored One. They all bowed at the Buddha's feet and sat to one side.
At that time, the World-Honored Buddha, seeing the assembly seated, told Nanda:

I have the essential Dharma, which is good in the beginning, middle, and end, with skillful words and meaning, pure and perfect in the pure and white practice of brahmacarya, namely the SÅ«tra on Entering the Mother's Womb.
You should listen attentively, focus your utmost attention, and think about it well.
I will now explain it for you.
Nanda said:
Yes, World-Honored One!
I wish to hear it with joy.
The Buddha told Nanda:
Although there is a mother's womb, there is entering and not entering.
How does one enter the mother's womb to receive birth?

If the parents have lustful thoughts and engage in sexual intercourse, if the mother's womb is clean and her menstrual period has arrived, and if the intermediate existence appears before them, one should know that at that time it is called entering the mother's womb.
Here, the form of the intermediate existence is of two kinds:
One is well-proportioned and upright, and the other is ugly.ğŸ”½The intermediate existence in hell has an ugly appearance like a burnt stump;
The intermediate existence of animals is smoky in color;
The intermediate existence of hungry ghosts is watery in color;
The intermediate existence of humans and gods has a golden-colored form;
The intermediate existence of the form realm is white in color;
The gods of the formless realm originally have no intermediate existence, because they are formless.

Sentient beings in the intermediate state may have two hands and two feet, or four feet or many feet, or no feet, according to their past karma and the place they are to be reborn. The intermediate state beings are shaped like those beings.
If they are to be reborn as gods, their heads point upward. Humans, animals, and ghosts move horizontally. Hell beings point their heads straight downward.
All intermediate state beings have spiritual powers and fly through the air. They are like the heavenly eye, observing from afar the place of rebirth.
When the menstrual period arrives means when the embryo is conceived.
Nanda!
Some women may have their period every three days, or every five days, or every half month or month, or there may be those who wait for a long time for their period to come.

If a woman has no power in her body and suffers much hardship, has an ugly appearance and no good food and drink, even if her period comes, it will soon stop, just like dry ground that is quickly dried when sprinkled with water.

If a woman has a powerful body and always enjoys comfort, has a dignified appearance, and obtains good food and drink, her menstrual period will not stop quickly, just like wet ground that is difficult to dry when sprinkled with water.
Why does it not enter?

When the father's essence comes out, the mother's essence does not come out, or when the mother's essence comes out, the father's essence does not come out, or if neither comes out, it does not receive a womb.

If the mother is impure and the father is pure, or if the father is impure and the mother is pure, or if both are impure, it also does not receive a womb.ğŸ”½If the mother's vagina is held by wind illness, or if there is jaundice, phlegm, or blood
qi in the womb, or if there is an increase in flesh, or if she takes medicine, or if she has stomach problems like an ant waist,
or if the birth canal is like a camel's mouth, or if it is like a tree with many roots, or like a plow head,
or like a chariot yoke, or like a rattan cane, or like a tree leaf, or like a wheat awn,
Some have deep bellies, some have deep upper [parts], some are not suitable for carrying a fetus, some always have blood flow,
some have water flowing, some are like a crow's mouth always open and not closed, some are not equal in width and narrowness on the top, bottom, and four sides,
some are uneven inside, some are eaten by worms and rotted and impure. If the mother has these faults, she will not conceive.
If the parents are noble and the intermediate being is lowly, or if the intermediate being is noble and the parents are lowly, such types will also not conceive.
If the parents and the intermediate being are all noble, if the karma is not in harmony, it will also not conceive.
If the intermediate being has no love for either gender in the previous realm, it will also not be reborn.
Nandi!
How does the intermediate being enter the mother's womb?

If the mother's womb is pure, the intermediate state being will directly see sexual activity, without the many faults mentioned above. Only if there is karmic affinity between the parents and the child will it enter the mother's womb.
Moreover, when that intermediate state being wishes to enter the womb, its mind becomes inverted.
If it is to be a male, it will feel love for the mother and hatred for the father.
If it is to be a female, it will feel love for the father and hatred for the mother.

It will give rise to deluded thoughts and make wrong judgments based on the karma it has created in past lives, thinking of cold weather, strong winds, heavy rain, clouds and fog, or hearing the noise of a large crowd.
Having had these thoughts, it will further give rise to ten kinds of deluded thoughts based on its superior or inferior karma.
What are the ten?

I am now entering a house, I want to climb a tower, I am ascending a palace, I am ascending a bed, I am entering a grass hut, I am entering a leaf hut, I am entering a thicket of grass, I am entering a forest, I am entering a hole in a wall, I am entering an opening in a fence.
Nanda!
At that time, some have this thought, and then enter the mother's womb.

One should know that the one who is born is called kalala, which is not made of anything else, but is made of the father's semen and the mother's blood. Due to the combination of the father's and mother's semen and blood, it becomes the object of consciousness and abides there.
It is like relying on a churning stick, a churning rope, and human effort to churn milk to produce butter. It does not arise from anything else.
One should know that the body of kalala, which is the impure semen and blood of the parents, is also like this.
Furthermore, Nanda!
There are four analogies, you should listen well.

It is like relying on green grass for insects to be born. The grass is not the insect, and the insect is not separate from the grass. However, relying on the grass, due to the combination of causes and conditions, the insects are born and their bodies become green.

Nanda should know that the body of kalala, which is the semen and blood of the father and mother, is also like this. Due to the combination of causes and conditions, the great elements and faculties are born.

It is like worms born from cow dung - the dung is not the worms, and the worms are not separate from the dung, but rather, depending on the dung as conditions come together, the worms are born with bodies that are yellow.

Nandi, you should know that the body of the kalala formed from the father's semen and mother's blood is also like this, with the great elements and faculties born from the coming together of conditions.

It is like worms born from jujube fruit - the jujube is not the worms, and the worms are not separate from the jujube, but rather, depending on the jujube as conditions come together, the worms are born with bodies that are red.
Nandi, you should know that the body of the kalala formed from the father's semen and mother's blood is also like this.
The great elements and faculties are born from the coming together of conditions.
It is like worms born from curd with bodies that are white, and so on, with the great elements and faculties born from the coming together of conditions.
Furthermore, Nandi!
Because of the kalala formed from the impure substances of the parents, the earth element appears, with the nature of solidity and hardness.
The water element appears, with the nature of moisture and wetness.
The fire element manifests, with warmth as its nature.
The wind element manifests, with lightness and movement as its nature.
Nan-t'o!
If the body of the kalala, the impurity of the parents, only has the earth element and no water element, it will then be dry and all scattered.
It is like the hands grasping dry flour and ash, etc.

If it only has the water element and no earth element, it will then separate, like oil drops in water. Because of the water element, the earth element does not scatter. Because of the earth element, the water element does not flow.
Nan-t'o!
If the body of the kalala only has the earth and water elements and no fire element, it will then rot and decay, like a lump of meat in a shady place during the summer months.
Nan-t'o, if the body of the kalala only has the earth, water, and fire elements and no wind element, it will then be unable to grow and expand.

All of these are due to past karma as the cause, mutually serving as conditions, and collectively attracting the consciousness to arise. The earth element can support, the water element can gather, the fire element can ripen, and the wind element can grow.
Nandi!
It is also like a person or their disciple who skillfully processes sugar cane, then blows on it to make it expand, with the inside hollow like a lotus root.
The great elements of the body, earth, water, fire, and wind, increase and grow due to the power of karma in the same way.
Nandi!

The impurities of the parents do not have the body of the kalala, nor is it the mother's womb, nor is it karma, nor is it a cause or condition, but it is only by the convergence of these many conditions that the embryo begins to exist.

Like a new seed that is not damaged by wind or sun, solid and without holes, stored appropriately, planted in good soil and also moist, the causes and conditions come together and then the sprout, stem, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits grow in sequence.
Nandi!
These seeds do not produce sprouts apart from the combination of conditions.

In the same way, you should know that the fetus is not born from the parents alone, nor from karma alone, nor from other conditions alone, but only when the causes and conditions of the parents' semen and blood combine.
Nanda!
Just as a person with clear eyes, in order to seek fire, places a sun-stone in the sun, and then places dry cow dung on top of it, only then does fire arise.
In the same way, you should know that the fetus is born only when the causes and conditions of the parents' semen and blood combine.
The parents' impurities form the kalala, which is called form. Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are its name, and it is called name-and-form.
This aggregate of detestable name-and-form takes birth in all existences, and I do not praise even a little bit of it for a moment.
Why is it so?
Being born in all existences is great suffering.
It is just like a little bit of excrement still having a foul smell.
In this way, you should know that being born in any existence is also suffering.
These five appropriated aggregates - form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness - all have birth, abiding, growth, and decay.
Birth is suffering, abiding is sickness, growth and decay are old age and death.
Therefore, Nanda!
Who would take pleasure in the ocean of existence, and lie in the mother's womb to undergo such intense suffering?
Furthermore, Nanda!
In this way, you should know that generally speaking, those who enter the womb stay there for thirty-eight seven-day periods.

In the first seven days, the fetus dwells in the mother's abdomen, like a thorn or a boil, lying in filth as if in a cauldron, with the body faculties and consciousness dwelling in one place, fiercely heated and simmered, undergoing extreme hardship, called kalala.

It is like porridge or whey, and for seven days it is boiled by internal heat. The solid nature of the earth element, the wet nature of the water element, the hot nature of the fire element, and the moving nature of the wind element only then manifest.
Nandi!

In the second seven days, the fetus resides in the mother's womb, lying in filth as if in a cauldron, with the sense faculties and consciousness dwelling in one place, strongly heated and boiled, suffering extreme hardship.
In the mother's womb there is a wind that arises by itself, called universal touch, born from past karma, which touches the fetus and is called arbuda.
It is like thick curds or coagulated butter, and for seven days it is boiled by internal heat, with the four elements manifesting.
Nandi!
The third seven days are described in detail as before.
In the mother's womb there is a wind, called knife mouth, born from past karma, which touches the fetus and is called pÄ“his.
Its appearance is like an iron chopstick or an earthworm, and in seven days the four elements manifest.
Nan-t'o!
The fourth seven days are explained in detail as before.
In the mother's womb there is wind, called the inner gate, born from past karma.
It blows on the fetus arrow, called Kan-nan.
Its appearance is like a shoe horn or a heated stone, and in seven days the four elements manifest.
Nan-t'o!
The fifth seven days are explained in detail as before.
In the mother's womb there is wind, called grasping.
This wind touches the fetus and five characteristics appear, namely the two arms, two thighs, and head.
It is like when the spring rains descend from the heavens, the trees and forests flourish and grow branches and leaves.
This is also like that, with the five characteristics appearing.
Nan-t'o!
The sixth seven days, in the mother's womb there is wind, called vast.
When this wind touches the fetus, four signs appear, namely the two elbows and two knees.
Like spring rains causing grass sprouts to grow,
this is also like that, with four signs appearing.
Nan-t'o!
On the seventh seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called revolving.
When this wind touches the fetus, four signs appear, namely the two hands and two feet.
Like foam or water moss, there are these four signs.
Nan-t'o!
On the eighth seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called turning over.
When this wind touches the fetus, twenty signs appear, namely the ten fingers and toes first emerge from this.
Like a new rain, tree roots first grow.
Nan-t'o!
On the ninth seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called dispersing.
When this wind touches the fetus, nine kinds of appearances manifest, namely the two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, and the mouth, as well as the two lower orifices.
Nandi!
On the seventeenth day, there is a wind in the mother's womb called hard and solid, which makes the fetus firm and solid.
On this very seventh day, there is a wind in the mother's womb called universal gate.
This wind blows and expands the womb, just like a floating bag filled with air.
Nandi!
On the eleventh seventh day, there is a wind in the mother's womb called permeable.
This wind touches the fetus, causing the fetus to become permeable with nine orifices appearing.
If the mother moves, stands, sits, or lies down and engages in activities, that wind circulates and gradually enlarges the orifices.
If the wind moves upward, the upper orifices open;
if it moves downward, it connects with the lower orifices.
It is like a blacksmith or his apprentice blowing on the bellows, the air going up and down, the wind doing its work and then disappearing.
Nan-t'o!
On the twelfth seventh day, there is a wind in the mother's womb called curved mouth.
This wind blows on the fetus, creating the large and small intestines on the left and right sides, like lotus fibers, thus relying on the body and abiding.

On this seventh day, there is also a wind called piercing hair, which creates one hundred and thirty joints in the fetus, neither increasing nor decreasing, and also creates one hundred and one forbidden places by the power of the wind.
Nan-t'o!

On the thirteenth seventh day, in the mother's womb, due to the power of the previous wind, one knows there is hunger and thirst. When the mother eats and drinks, the flavors enter from the navel and are used to nourish the body.
Nan-t'o!
On the fourteenth seventh day, there is a wind in the mother's womb called thread mouth.
That wind causes the fetus to produce one thousand sinews:
Two hundred and fifty in front of the body, two hundred and fifty behind the body, two hundred and fifty on the right side, and two hundred and fifty on the left side.
Nanda!
On the fifteenth week, there is a wind in the mother's womb called lotus.
It can create twenty kinds of channels for the fetus to absorb various flavors;
five in front of the body, five behind the body, five on the right side, and five on the left side.
The channels have various names and colors, such as companion, strength, and power.
The colors are blue, yellow, red, white, beans, ghee, oil, yogurt, and so on, with many colors mixed together.
Nanda!
The twenty channels each have forty channels as their retinue, totaling eight hundred inhalation channels, with two hundred each in the front, back, left, and right of the body.
Nanda!
These eight hundred channels each have one hundred subsidiary channels connected to them, totaling eighty thousand:
twenty thousand in the front, twenty thousand in the back, twenty thousand on the right, and twenty thousand on the left.
Nan-t'o!
These eighty thousand channels also have many pores, either one pore, two pores, up to seven pores, each connected to the hair pores, just like a lotus root with many gaps.
Nan-t'o!
On the sixteenth week, in the mother's womb there is a wind called nectar-like action.
This wind can create the conditions for placing the fetus's two eyes in their proper locations.
Thus, the two ears, two noses, mouth, throat, chest, and the place where food enters and is stored, enabling the passage of exhalation and inhalation.
It is like a potter and his disciples taking a good lump of clay and placing it on a wheel, arranging it according to the shape and form of the vessel, making sure there are no errors.
This is done by the wind of karma, which arranges them in the eyes and other places according to its power, and can even cause them to pass through the in- and out-breaths without any error.
Nandi!
On the seventeenth week, there is a wind in the mother's womb called broom mouth.

This wind can make the eyes, ears, nose, mouth, throat, chest, and places where food enters of the fetus smooth and slippery, and it can make the in- and out-breaths pass through and establish their locations.
It is like a skilled craftsman or his male or female apprentices, who take a dusty mirror and polish it with oil, ash, or fine soil to make it clean.
This is done by the wind of karma, which arranges the locations without obstruction.
Nandi!
On the eighteenth week, there is a wind in the mother's womb called stainless.

It can make the six sense bases of the fetus pure and clear, just as when the orb of the sun or moon is greatly covered by clouds, a strong wind suddenly arises, blows the clouds away in all directions, and the orb of light becomes pure and clear.
Nanda!
The power of this karmic wind causes the six sense faculties of the fetus to become pure, in the same way.
Nanda!
On the nineteenth week, in the mother's womb, it causes the fetus to perfect four sense faculties:
eyes, ears, nose, and tongue.
When entering the mother's womb, one first obtains three faculties, namely body, life, and mind.
Nanda!
On the twenty-seventh day, in the mother's womb, there is a wind called firm and solid.

This wind, relying on the fetus's left foot, produces twenty bones in the toes, and the right foot also produces twenty bones. There are four bones in the heel, two bones in the forearm, two bones in the knee, two bones in the calf, three bones in the hip, and eighteen bones in the spine. There are twenty-four bones in the ribs.
It also relies on the left hand to produce twenty bones in the fingers, and it also produces twenty bones in the right hand.

There are two bones in the forearm, four bones in the arm, seven bones in the chest, seven bones in the shoulder, four bones in the neck, two bones in the jaw, thirty-two bones in the teeth, and four bones in the skull.
Nan-t'o!
It is like a plasterer or his disciple first using a hard wood to make the shape, then wrapping it with rope, and finally applying the plaster to form the image.
The power of this karmic wind arranges the bones in the same way.
Among them, there are two hundred large bones, excluding the other small bones.
Nan-t'o!
On the twenty-first seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called arising.
It can cause flesh to grow on the fetus's body.
It is like a potter first kneading the clay well and then plastering it on walls.
This wind producing flesh is also like this.
Nan-t'o!
On the twenty-second seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called floating and flowing.
This wind can cause blood to be produced in the fetus.
Nanda!
On the twenty-third seven-day period, there is a wind in the mother's womb called Pure Holder.
This wind can cause skin to be produced in the fetus.
Nanda!
On the twenty-fourth seven-day period, there is a wind in the mother's womb called Spreading.
This wind can cause the fetus' skin to be radiant.
Nanda!
On the twenty-fifth seven-day period, there is a wind in the mother's womb called Holder of the City.
This wind can cause the fetus' blood and flesh to be nourished.
Nanda!
On the twenty-sixth seven-day period, there is a wind in the mother's womb called Production.
It can cause hair, body hair, and nails to grow on the fetus' body, all of which are connected to the vessels one by one.
Nanda!
On the twenty-seventh seven-day period, there is a wind in the mother's womb called Curved Medicine.
This wind can cause the hair, body hair, and nails of the fetus to be fully formed.
Nandaka!

Due to the fetus's previous evil karma, stinginess and miserliness, firm attachment to wealth and property, unwillingness to give in charity, and not accepting the teachings of parents and elders, unwholesome karma is created by body, speech, and mind, increasing day and night, and one will receive this retribution.
If reborn as a human, the fruits and rewards obtained will all be unsatisfactory.ğŸ”½If people consider long to be good, they will be short.
If they consider short to be good, they will be long.ğŸ”½If they consider coarse to be good, they will be fine.
If they consider fine to be good, they will be coarse.ğŸ”½If they consider close-knit limbs to be good, they will be separated.
If they consider separation to be good, they will be close.ğŸ”½If they consider many to be good, they will be few.
If they consider few to be good, they will be many.

If one likes fat, one becomes thin; if one likes thin, one becomes fat. If one likes fearlessness, one becomes timid; if one likes timidity, one becomes fearless. If one likes white, one becomes black; if one likes black, one becomes white.
Nan-t'o!

Moreover, due to evil karma one receives evil retribution, being deaf, blind, mute, stupid, ugly, and the sounds one makes are unpleasant to hear. One's hands and feet are crippled, and one's form is like a hungry ghost.
One's relatives all hate one and do not want to see one, let alone other people.
When one speaks with one's three karmas towards others, they do not believe or accept it and do not take it to heart.
Why is this so?
It is because in one's previous lives one created evil karma and thus receives such retribution.
Nan-t'o!

Due to the fetus's cultivation of meritorious karma in the past, one likes to give generously, is not stingy, has compassion for the poor and destitute, and has no stingy or attached mind towards various possessions. The good karma one creates increases day and night, and one will receive excellent retribution.
If one is born among humans, the fruits of retribution one receives will all be in accordance with one's wishes.
If the people of the world consider long to be good, then one will be long.
If they prefer short, then it is short.

The size of the body is just right, with well-proportioned limbs, neither too much nor too little fat or thin, neither too brave nor too timid, with a complexion that everyone loves, and all six sense faculties complete, with a countenance that surpasses others, clear speech, and a harmonious and elegant voice. All the physical characteristics are complete, and those who see it rejoice.
When speaking with others using the three karmas, others all believe and accept it, and respectfully keep it in their minds.
Why is this so?
Because in their past lives they created various wholesome karmas, and thus they receive such rewards.
Nanda!
If the fetus is a boy, it will squat and sit on the right side of the mother, covering its face with both hands and facing the mother's spine.
If it is a girl, it will squat and sit on the left side of the mother, covering its face with both hands and facing the mother's abdomen.
It is below the raw intestines and above the cooked intestines, with the raw food pressing down below and the cooked food piercing above, like being tied to five places and stabbed with sharp stakes.

If the mother eats too much or too little, she suffers pain. In this way, if she eats too much grease, or too little, or too much cold, too much heat, too salty, too bland, too bitter, too sour, too sweet, or too spicy, when she eats these things, she all suffers pain.
If the mother has sex, or runs too fast, or sits in a dangerous position for a long time, or sits or lies down for a long time, or jumps around, she all suffers pain.
Nan-t'o should know that there are such various kinds of suffering in the mother's womb that oppress her body, which cannot be fully described.
In the human realm, one suffers such suffering, let alone in the evil realms of hell, where the suffering is difficult to compare.
Therefore, Nan-t'o!
Who has wisdom and delights in dwelling in the boundless sea of suffering of birth and death, to undergo such misfortune?
Nan-t'o!
On the twenty-eighth seventh day, in the mother's womb, the fetus gives rise to eight kinds of inverted thoughts.
What are the eight?
Namely, the thoughts of a house, a vehicle, a garden, a pavilion, a forest, a bed, a river, and a pond, all of which are falsely imagined without any real objects.
Nan-t'o!
On the twenty-ninth seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called flower pattern.
This wind can blow on the fetus, causing its complexion to be fresh, white, and clean.
Or, due to the power of karma, it causes the color to be dark, or even blue, with various other kinds of complexions.
Or it causes it to be dry and without moisture, with white and black lights coming out according to the color.
Nan-t'o!
On the thirtieth seven days, there is a wind in the mother's womb called iron mouth.
This wind can blow on the fetus's hair, body hair, and nails, causing them to grow, with white and black lights all appearing according to karma, as explained above.
Nan-t'o!
On the thirty-first seven days, the fetus gradually grows larger in the mother's womb.
In this way, for thirty-two, thirty-three, and thirty-four seven-day periods, it grows and expands.
Nan-t'o!
On the thirty-fifth seven-day period, the child's limbs are complete in the mother's womb.
Nan-t'o!
On the thirty-sixth seven-day period, the child is unhappy staying in the mother's womb.
Nan-t'o!

On the thirty-seventh seven-day period, in the mother's womb, the child then gives rise to three kinds of non-inverted thoughts, namely the thought of impurity, the thought of foul stench, and the thought of darkness, speaking from one aspect.
Nan-t'o!
On the thirty-eighth seven-day period, in the mother's womb there is wind, called blue flower.
This wind can cause the child to turn its body downward, stretch out both arms, and head towards the birth canal.

Next, there is wind called downward-moving. Due to the power of karma, the wind blows the child in the womb, causing its head to face downward and its two feet to face upward, about to emerge from the birth canal.
Nan-t'o!

If the fetus in the womb has committed many evil deeds in its previous life and has fallen into the human womb, by this cause and condition, when it is about to be born, its hands and feet are twisted and cannot turn, and it dies in the mother's womb.

At that time, a wise woman or a good doctor, with warm ghee or oil, or elm bark juice and other slippery substances, smears her hands, and then inserts a thin knife as sharp as a blade with her middle finger.

In this filthy place, which is like a dark and foul-smelling pit of excrement, inhabited by countless thousands of insects, with a constantly flowing foul liquid, putrid blood and semen, deeply disgusting, covered by a thin skin, and an evil karma-born wound on the body.
In this filthy place, she pushes her hand in and uses the sharp knife to cut the child's body into pieces and pull it out.
The mother, because of this, suffers unbearable extreme pain and hardship, and dies because of this;
Even if she manages to survive, it is no different from death.
Nandana!
If the fetus is due to the child's good karma, even if it is upside down, it will not harm the mother, and she will give birth safely without suffering.
Nan-t'o!

If it is an ordinary birth without this calamity, when the thirty-eighth week arrives and it is about to be born, the mother will suffer greatly and her life will be in danger before she can give birth.
Nan-t'o!
